s.text: An article heralds the rise of the worm industry ("vermiculture"): Worms are a cheap, environmentally sound way of turning garbage into fertilizer.
To remain relevant, labor must take risks and build its membership (current growth rate: less than 2 percent per year).
Crime may be down, but public schools are as lousy as ever, and the unemployment rate is one of the highest in the nation.
To remain relevant, labor must take risks and build its membership (current growth rate: less than 2 percent per year).
Crime may be down, but public schools are as lousy as ever, and the unemployment rate is one of the highest in the nation.
An essay by Mother Teresa basher Christopher Hitchens likens the nun to Princess Di: Both used the poor and sick as "accessories" in "the service and the pursuit of the rich and powerful."
The "New Establishment 1997" ranks "the 50 most powerful players of the Information Age."
Sex Pistols manager Malcolm McLaren chronicles his wild '70s life, focusing on Sid Vicious' 1978 arrest for his girlfriend's murder.
The cover story credits Julia Child with "invent[ing] modern life."
An article on the JonBenet Ramsey case presents evidence that strongly suggests her parents killed her.

Among many highlights: McLaren fences sound equipment stolen by the Sex Pistols from David Bowie's house; McLaren rejects William Kunstler as Vicious' defense attorney because he listens to "Bob Dylan or Joan Baez--possibly even Joni Mitchell"; McLaren tries to sanitize Vicious' image by finding him a "librarian" girlfriend.
Newsweek devotes the cover package to Mother Teresa, asking when she will be sainted.
